channel.title: Horrible Wifi/Ethernet
channel.description:
Does anyone know why a router with a 300mbps speed and a ISP with a promised 75mbps speed fails to download/upload past a 200kbps speed? I've upgraded the firmware, turned off any devices that use WiFi, changes plenty router specifications, and even tried google for my help. My router isn't upgradeable to DD-WRT, which really sucks :mad:
My average download speed is around 70-110kbps and on a really really good day 200kbps. Would anyone know why a download/upload speed can be this horrible?
My modem is right beside the computer on a wooden stand with no other devices.

item.title: Horrible Wifi/Ethernet
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“wildskiller, post:7, topic:548734”][quote author=sk8rdude461 link=topic=667642.msg4465031#msg4465031 date=1419544298]

When this happened, I contacted comcast (My ISP) and they said my router/modem were outdated. Apparently my router was a DOCSIS 2.0 device and they had upgraded their stuff to a DOCSIS 3.0, causing my router to reach it’s “end of life”…
How that all caused my internet speed to go from 30-40mb/s to .1kb/s, I have no idea. But when they gave me the new equipment, all was good.
May/May not be helpful:
http://mydeviceinfo.comcast.net/

My ISP has given me this router just 2 months ago (ReadyNet WRT-500, 2.4GHz, 801.11g), and I have recently updated my firmware. My current connection speed is 150mbps, so I don’t understand AT ALL why in the world this connection could be so slow.

ReadyNet looks like some off brand routers (I’m judging by their website…). http://www.readynetsolutions.com/products/wrt500-wireless-n-router-with-tr-069/
That’s what I found when trying to look for information in your router, but they really didn’t provide much. I also found a setup guide and the directory is in a wordpress folder… So I mean, they probably aren’t that good if they’re using wordpress… http://www.readynetsolutions.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/07/WRT500-QIG_140520_0900.pdf (They could have used it in the past and never updated the folder… idk but still).

I think your next step would be bitching to your isp about your speeds. That’s really the only way I get my shit fixed if it does go down.
[/quote]
The way the website looks shouldn’t matter; the way the specs are should. The price of this router was $60, and that’s a pretty good price range for what the router offers.[/quote]
If they cannot afford a ‘premium’ website (one not built off an existing engine… like wordpress) do you really think they can afford quality parts?

Read full topic

item.title: Horrible Wifi/Ethernet
item.dc:creator: @Ix_Soulcist_xI Soulcist
item.description:
@Ix_Soulcist_xI wrote:

wildskiller:

The way the website looks shouldn’t matter; the way the specs are should. The price of this router was $60, and that’s a pretty good price range for what the router offers.

If you want to advertise out a product, you’re not going to want to make the source of the product (e.g. advertising on a website) look like complete shit would you? Either or, if you are having problems with the router or ISP itself, call them for like the fourth time being told lmao.

They obviously must have given you a defected router, or it simply was a mishap or something. I’m not sure what else to tell you besides to call them.

Read full topic

Bowser jr:

Have you exceeded your ISP’s bandwidth limit?

Not even close, the internet has been like this since the day I got it
